name: MI Child Development & Care Program
provider: Michigan Department of Lifelong Education, Advancement, and Potential
description: The Office of Child Development and Care (CDC) supports low-income working families by providing access to affordable, high-quality early care and afterschool programs by supporting numerous efforts designed to assess and improve the level of quality across the spectrum of Michigan's early learning and care settings.
requirements: Child under 13 (or up to 18 with special needs)
Valid need for care (work, education, or treatment program)
Income eligibility (expanded recently - up to 185% of federal poverty level)

This program provides payment assistance to help eligible parents pay for child care, with parents qualifying if they are working, attending education/training, or participating in approved counseling/treatment programs

name: MI Great Start Readiness Program (GSRP)
provider: Michigan Department of Lifelong Education, Advancement, and Potential
description: Michigan's free PreK program for eligible four-year-olds. Ranked #1 in the U.S., it's a safe place where children learn how to get along with others, share, take turns, and make friends. Math, reading, and thinking skills are taught every day through fun, hands-on activities.
requirements: Those who do not qualify for or do not have access to Head Start

name: Early Head Start Program
description: Early Head Start is a free federal program that provides support to low-income families of infants and toddlers under the age of 3 and pregnant women. The program provides a wide range of high-quality education, health, nutrition, family support, and social services to enrolled infants and toddlers, pregnant women and their families.

name: Head Start Preschool Program
description: Preschool education program offering a developmentally appropriate curriculum for 3 and 4 year olds

name: 4C of the UP (Child Care Coordinating Council)
description: This organization supports child care providers and helps families locate care.
